data.title: Good huancaina, poor ceviche
data.text:
After applying for a Peruvian passport renewal, I walked across the street to this restaurant and ordered two dishes:  papas a la huancaina and ceviche.

The papas (boiled potatoes with a creamy, spicy yellow sauce on top of it, served cold on a bed of lettuce and garnished with olives, was delicious.

However, the ceviche, a raw white fish (usually flounder, tilapia, orange roughy, etc. in the U.S.), which is chemically cooked in lime juice, was undercooked chemically and tasted like raw fish. I grew up in Peru eating lots of ceviche and this was definitely undercooked, chemically. The ceviche, although technically raw, is not supposed to taste raw after it marinates in lime juice for a few hours.

I'll give the benefit of the doubt to the restaurant and chalk it up to me coming in around 11:30 a.m. for lunch and they probably not really having the ceviche fully ready. If that was the case, though, they should not have served it to me.

Peruvian food is some of the most delicious in the world and I'd hate for an experience like this to unfairly taint a "newbie's" view of Peruvian food.

data.title: Riquísima la comida
data.text: Cada vez que voy es pedirme una jalea o un bisteck a lo pobre, la comida es buenísima y sobre todo de buena proporción, atención excelente y sobre todo es un rinconcito de nuestro Peru maravilloso :)
